title: Tweed and Don; or, Recollections and reflections of an angler for the last fifty years ...
author: Locke, James.
snippet: One of our great days was to the Esk at this place, after long looking and longing for the fast- day or other holiday. I have seen four or five of us boys start for it, after buying a hook or two from Somerville's in Leith Street ; the kind old gentleman for all the shopkeepers there were then gentlemen giving us some good instructions  how to throw our lines without sleech- ing off our hooks. title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Dick Bailie, in appearance a gentleman, but in reality asmart thief, entered a jeweller's shop in Leith Street one after-noon, having first seen the proprietor safely away to dinner. The shopman left to attend to the business was a lad of nine-teen, a nephew of the jeweller, named Colin M'Letchie.

title: Skagboys
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: Cutting down LothianRoad, she walked to the east end through Princes Street Gardens. Headingdown Leith Street, then Leith Walk and reaching her Pilrig flat, she hungup her jacket.Then she looked at herself in the bathroom mirror.Thoughtabout her mum, how she loved to meet her for a coffee, to show her atop or shoes she'd bought, to gossip about neighbours or relatives, or talkabout what they'd watched on the telly. Soaping and rinsing her hands,she recalled that she'd put the towels in the wash basket.
